question.title: Need clarity about Java AccessibleObject
question.body:
I have a question about the Java AccessibleObject class. The documentation says that "reflected objects assume readability".

If all I am trying to do is read the value of a member field in the Object, does that mean that I can safely assume that I do have "read" access and do not need to call the setAccessible() method?

question_comments.body: That section is about modules, specificially the runtime version of the "requires" directive in a module-info.java-File (If you don't knwo what that is, you probbably don't have one).

And the sentence "Whether the checks for Java language access control can be suppressed (and thus, whether access can be enabled) depends on whether the reflected object corresponds to a member in an exported or open package (see setAccessible(boolean)).". In any case, if it's not public, you must call setAccessible, and that will only work if the package is open or exported from the module.

Did you read the following sentence which explains what they mean with that: "That is, the module containing the use of a reflected object is assumed to read the module in which the underlying field, method, or constructor is declared."
